The siddur includes extensive use of Hebrew calligraphy (rather than typeset Hebrew), as well as transliterated (romanized) Hebrew. Rabbi Ravetch provides an extensive introduction to his siddur which attests to his orientation to á¸¤asidut and traditional Judaism.

This work is in the Public Domain due to the lack of a copyright renewal by the copyright holder listed in the copyright notice (a condition required for works published in the United States between January 1st 1924 and January 1st 1964).

This digital edition was prepared by Aharon Varady from page images made of an item in his personal collection of siddurim. (Thank you!)

This is an attempt to present the traditional Sabbath Eve service through an understandable, devotional approach. The Hebrew prayers have been transliterated so that even those who have no knowledge whatever of our sacred tongue will be able to follow the chants and responses. To enable the worshipper to tell at a glance when he is to read, all responses and unison readings are clearly marked. Five variations for five Sabbaths are suggested. They have been used in the synagogue and were found helpful in giving fuller and more meaningful expression to the service.

USE OF HEBREW

Israel knows languages, but has forgotten Hebrew. The importance of Hebrew, the language for Jewish prayer, cannot be overstressed. Hebrew is the language of holiness, saturated with sacred memories since the day man first heard the voice of God from Mount Horeb. Even those who do not understand Hebrew are stirred by its rhythm and majestic cadences. Those who know even a little Hebrew will readily conceive how futile, how unreliable even the best translation must be. Often the best translation distorts the fundamental concepts of our faith. No other language can equal Hebrew as a vehicle for prayer. Moreover, Hebrew is common to all Jews, and has been throughout the ages the mortar that cemented Israel. If we are in earnest about keeping the historical continuity of our people, if we want to develop the sense of Jewish oneness, Hebrew is the only instrument for that task.

But Hebrew must sound like Hebrew; words must be pronounced clearly, and not degraded to mumbo jumbo. The Hebrew prayers and responses should not be rushed, and maimed.
